I'm guessing this is a hard "no"? https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-06-20/saudi-moves-forward-with-plan-to-turn-qatar-into-island "Saudi Arabia is moving forward with a plan to dig a canal that would physically enshrine its yearlong rift with Qatar by turning the emirate from a peninsula bordering the kingdom into an island, Saudi media reported on Tuesday. "Five international companies that specialize in digging canals have been invited to vie for the project, with bids closing on Monday and the winner to be chosen within 90 days, Makkah newspaper reported, citing unidentified people familiar with the matter. The canal should be completed within one year of work starting, it said. The report was also carried by Saudi-owned news channel Al Arabiya and shared on Twitter by Saudi royal court adviser Saud Al Qahtani. "The Saudi government’s Center for International Communication didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment. The government has never confirmed the plan, first reported in April. "The project, if it is carried out, would geographically extend Qatar’s isolation from Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt after they cut trade and diplomatic ties with the emirate last year. The allies accused Qatar of supporting terrorism and meddling in their affairs, charges it denies. "In April, media reported that the channel would be 60 kilometers (37.5 miles) long and 200 meters (219 yards) wide, running the entire length of the strip of Saudi territory that borders Qatar. Part of the canal zone would be set aside for a planned nuclear waste facility, Al Riyadh newspaper reported, and Sabq online newspaper said the canal project could cost up to 2.8 billion riyals ($750 million)."

This would amount to a repudiation of Saudi Arabia’s 13 demands and so is not a concession they will make in this short time span.

Qatar is already picking up the tab, as it absorbs the huge costs of regional isolation, despite its vast wealth in gas resources.Kuwait's deputy foreign minister, Khaled al-Jarallah, said diplomatic efforts are "ongoing". "The latest of these efforts and ideas will be presented during a Gulf-American summit in September, and this summit will be an opportunity to end this crisis," he told AFP.

The current row between Qatar and other Gulf States, such as Saudi Arabia, dates back decades and is unlikely to be resolved soon. Although all countries share the same peninsula, their domestic and foreign policy goals differ greatly, especially the foreign policy of Qatar. The current row can be traced back to the mid-90's when Qatar launched Al-Jazeera, which began to increasingly cover news in the Arab world, putting the regions issues on the world spotlight and much to the annoyance of its gulf neighbors. In addition, with the rise of the Arab Spring and  new conflicts, Qatar has been accused of sending aid to groups at odds with its gulf neighbors, such as Saudi Arabia and the UAE. The current standoff has also forced Qatar to make better ties with Iran, which is strategically and economically viable, as Qatar and Iran share gas fields. However, this alliance is unacceptable to the other Arab powers. In addition, Turkey and Russia have also voiced their support for Qatar, which are two countries with different goals in the region. It has also been interpreted that Saudi Arabia and the other Arab countries are able to double down on the standoff, as the US has sent mixed messages and Trump's condemnation of Qatar for financing terrorist groups is emboldening other Arab countries in their standoff. Finally, Saudi Arabia is making heavy demands such as the closure of Al-Jazeera and severing ties with Iran as a prerequisite for ties to be normalized, which may be too costly for Qatar to accept. https://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/06/17/533054129/qatars-crisis-with-saudi-arabia-and-gulf-neighbors-has-decades-long-roots
https://www.ft.com/content/ed5af0b0-5fcd-11e7-8814-0ac7eb84e5f1
https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/22/world/middleeast/qatar-saudi-emir-boycott.html

Given that Saudi Arabia and Qatar displayed no prominent signals of reconciliation, I think it is very unlikely that Saudi Arabia would open it land border to Qatar before August 1, 2018. As long as Saudi Arabia maintains that Qatar is essentially an Iranian proxy, Saudi Arabia, alongside its neighbors, will keep on isolating Qatar. Adding to the unlikelihood of a truce is the possibility that Saudi Arabia is utilizing diversionary strategies while Qatar is most likely operating on the realist principle of balancing. Saudi Arabia is arguably targeting Qatar due to popular opposition to MBS’ “liberal” policies and to balance Iran by strengthening GCC and alienating Qatar, while Qatar is balancing against Saudi Arabia by aligning with Iran.

KSA conditions haven't been met by Qatar's Government, nothing has changed and there is no expectation of change. The leadership of Qatar and KSA have competing agendas, al Jazeera channel will continue to broadcast much to MbS annoyance.

The rhetoric shows no sign of subsiding and both sides seem to have adapted to the new status quo.  KSA is reportedly resisting US-efforts at mediation.  I've left a 10% margin for the possibility of the US efforts leading to a resolution.

A previous blockade  has had a duration of 8 Months. It seems that Quatar is not willing to back down and SA neither. Ending the blockade without any concessions from Qatar side would be a loss of face for the saudi king. Therefore it seems unlikely to come any time soon. On the other hand there seems not to be too much to gain from extending the blockae on GCC side. It seems to foster the relationship Quatar to Iran, which is an argument for GCC to end the blockade rather sooner than later. All in all i expect the blockade not to exceed the 1 year mark

The core issues that Kingdom of Saudi Arabia ("KSA") took with Qatar revolve around two issues: Qatar's continued economic cooperation with Iranian natural gas interests (Pars field) and Qatar's remarkably progressive laissez-faire attitude toward the content published by al Jazeera. Qatar has, at this point, established core water routes to deliver consumables to the kingdom, and derives too great a percentage of its national revenues from its rights to the South Pars field to put its economic cooperation with Tehran at risk. Moreover, there are shared infrastructure advantages to working with Iran to transport natural gas out of those fields than to development standalone infrastructure within Qatar to do so on its own. WIth regard to the continued operation of al Jazeera, it is likely Qatar would be willing to make it into a sacrificial lamb and shut it down, but given that it has already made the offer to KSA with the condition that KSA leave their existing relationship with Iran in place, and KSA refused, they no longer have much to gain by shutting it down without also making a decision on the Iranian relationship. Given they have chosen to prioritize their relationship with Iran out of economic interests, and that they are no longer looking at shutting al Jazeera down, it is unlikely KSA will agree to re-establish normal economic traffic across Qatar's land border in the foreseeable future. I assign it a rough 1 in 10 chance that a random event could cause Riyadh to change their minds prior to August.
Only reason under current situation would be for territorial expansion.
Turmoil in Saudi Royal family will freeze decision making process.

The Saudis are under no real pressure here. For Riyadh to publicly end its blockade without getting major concessions from Qatar would be a humiliating admission of failure. I can see the blockade remaining in place formally for several years while the Saudis let it informally erode into a return to the status quo ante in most areas.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-to-persian-gulf-resolve-qatar-crisis-or-no-camp-david/2018/03/02/0f0b452a-1de7-11e8-98f5-ceecfa8741b6_story.html?utm_term=.d02dc69b30cd "A potential summit of the six-country Gulf Cooperation Council in May at the prestigious presidential retreat in Maryland’s Catoctin Mountains will be scuttled unless Qatar and neighbors Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain are on track to resolve the nearly year-long spat. A pair of Trump administration emissaries will deliver the message next week as they crisscross the Gulf in a renewed bid to try to end the crisis." "It’s not clear that the Gulf countries even want to attend such a summit, which would require leaders who have spent the last eight months bashing Qatar to put all of that aside and pose for friendly group photo-ops. But if there’s one trait that unifies Qatar and its neighbors, it’s an unwavering desire to show they’re simpatico with Trump."

Saudi Arabia(aka"the big dog') has enormous influence in the region. I'm having a hard time reconciling Saudi and Qatar at each other's throats. It is unfortunate, but my heart goes to Qatar.
Given the talks at high level between Qatar and US and apparent transparency and guarantees given... It serves all at play to move on stick to what makes them allies with a common goal.

It is extremely unlikely that Saudi Arabia will reopen its land border with Qatar before August 2018. Neither country has expressed interest in negotiations, and the current diplomatic crisis between the two countries is nearing ten months. As long as Qatar maintains close ties with Iran, Saudi Arabia will continue (along with its neighbors) to shut out Qatar. At the end end of 2017,  the annual regional summit was cut short due to the ongoing crisis, and based upon the current actions and ties of the countries in the region, it doesn't seem likely that Saudi Arabia will reopen its land border with Qatar anytime soon. http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/saudi-arabia-permenantly-closes-land-border-qatar-1505851849, http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/12/saudi-permanently-closes-land-border-qatar-171220062311052.html
There seems to be no urgency about, nor even any interest in, doing this any time soon.
Still too much turmoil in the country

The Qataris and Saudis are both mounting diplomatic offensives against each other to win supporters, especially in the United States.  This takes time to pay off, so we have to wait.  The Qataris are good at this and the Saudis are in transition.

The new military and economic alliance between Saudi Arabia and the UAE will weaken any GCC attempts to moderate the end to political conflicts with Qatar. 
   The "coupe" in Saudi Arabia and consolidation of military and economic power by Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salam Al Saud (First Deputy Prime Minister, President of the Council for Economic and Development Affairs and Minister of Defense) is positioning
himself to become the power broker (and potential despot) in the region and thus puting himself into direct conflict with Qatar, the powerfully progressive, innovative and dynamic ally of the US and Turkey, who has economic and diplomatic ties to Iran. 
      The blockade will persist to allow the Saudi Crown Prince to attempt to consolidate his power and alliances economically, politically, and militarily in the region. 
    It does not behoove Saudi Arabia to end the blockade any time soon.

Both Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman and Qatari Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani remain firm in their positions to not concede to one another. Saudi Arabia wants Qatar to cut its ties to terrorism as well as decrease trade with Iran. However, Qatar continues to desire a position equal to, if not greater than, Saudi Arabia in the Gulf power structure. The border will likely remain closed for the foreseeable future. One unlikely scenario that could change this is if King Salman dies and MBS's challenger, Mohammed Bin Nayef, is able to return and take the throne.

not likely seems to be under threat from region

Saudia Arabia has broad support in closing it's boarders and is the most powerful country in the region, also leading the Oil industry there, so their ability to retaliate is strong. Qatar has strong international allies though, and will be able to hold out during long-term talks.
I can't see any pressure on Saudi to reopen the border, nor any immediate benefit, so I think the situation will be static in the medium-term.

It is likely that the current diplomatic spat will persist for some time because the underlying political forces do not favor rapprochement. Qatar is in the process of re-aligning with Turkey and Iran, while Saudi Arabia is in the process of a muscular foreign policy that includes a regional war with Yemen. Perhaps most importantly, the Trump administration has personal relationships with MBS and has supported provocative moves thus far that include an internal purge of Saudi billionaires, material assistance for their war with Yemen, and political cover for their hostility to Iran.  Saudi is historically highly sensitive to US pressure and with a supportive Trump administration, a thawing of relations with Qatar would probably only result if Qatar capitulated to some of the Saudi demands, which essentially asked Qatar to become a client state of Saudi Arabia.
This situation has legs and will continue for some time, it will most likely not be resolved this year.
It's too dangerous it may take several years.

Passing of time.  It seems KSA high officials have also had a war of words with Kuwaiti officials. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-kuwait/kuwait-protests-at-insult-by-saudi-official-agency-idUSKBN1FE1F1

among the parties involved it seems to me that only SA's perspective is relevant to the issue. US has kept a neutral stance. AE and BH are only followers to SA. IR and QA have strong economic ties but follow different doctrines. QA has rather limited options, e.g. enforcing ties with CN or RU for military cooperation or - unlikely - expel Al-Jazeera. however, among the thinkable options are compromises in the governance of Al-Jazeera and promises to withdraw funding of the muslim brotherhood. again the question is how strong SA is pushing in these points. prince mohammed ibn salman seems to be keen to get power over the media. weighing the options i see a 50% chance that the border will be open within six months.

This is a hard ball to call. The talks are slow but as long as the people talk they will open the border. The trading of goods depends on the open borders ...

I never thought the chances of a reconciliation were good in the short term, but after one of the most bizarre twists I've see lately, I'm lowering my forecast again.  I have no idea if it's true or not or is designed to make western allies and clients think Qatar's trying to be progressive or noble.  I wonder if it matters.  Doubling down on their denial of involvement with terrorism or Iran while making more public accusations is hardly likely to calm relations, which seem pretty stonewalled as present in any case and unlikely to get better while tensions & competition with Iran remain high.     "One of the biggest Middle East crises in years was caused by the wife of an asylum seeker living in Britain, Qatar's foreign minister claimed yesterday. Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani said his country's dispute with its Gulf neighbours began when it refused to hand the woman over to the United Arab Emirates. The mother-of-six and her husband, an unnamed Emirates opposition leader, fled to Qatar in 2013 during a period of political arrests against government opponents. "...The husband then moved to the UK where he sought asylum and was granted indefinite leave to remain. But his wife, who has now joined her husband in Britain, initially decided to stay in Qatar because she had family ties there. When she tried to renew her passport at the Emirates embassy her application was refused and the authorities demanded her extradition.  Qatar's refusal to comply with the request led to UAE stepping up its attacks on the Doha government on social media and in the wider mainstream press. "[...Repeated demands for extradition were] refused. Mr al-Thani said: 'Prince Tamim refused to extradite the woman because she was not wanted in a criminal offence, and this would be contrary to international law and the Qatari Constitution.' "Two months later, on 5 June, a Saudi-led alliance including the UAE launched a diplomatic and transport blockade of Qatar accusing it of cosying up to Iran and supporting terrorism, which Doha denies.  Among its list of 13 demands, the quartet of countries ordered that all political dissidents were handed back to their countries of origin.  "Later U.S. intelligence sources claimed the crisis had been sparked in June when the UAE hacked Qatar's official website and planted incendiary quotes which were attributed to the Emir, and praising the quartet's arch-enemy, Iran. This allowed Qatar's enemies to point the finger at Doha and claim it was a divisive force in the region...." http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-5263901/Qatar-crisis-began-did-not-hand-wanted-wife.html
http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/qatar-foreign-minister-claims-gulf-diplomatic-crisis-was-caused-by-one-womans-passport-1654969
https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/5328679/uae-politician-wife-hiding-britain-fears-torture-qatar/#comments
Every awful leader needs good news at some point.

The recent summit in Kuwait saw almost all of the GCC members sending lower level diplomats with the main point of the summit being to try to find a diplomatic solution to the land blockade of Qatar. During the summit, Saudi Arabia announced a new military and economic partnership with the UAE consequently weakening the GCC and perhaps any diplomatic gravitas it might hold   to resolve the Qatar issue.
   The land blockade has not been effective as Qatar's other allies have relieved most of any economic stress that the land blockade with Saudi Arabia has caused.
     There are still underlying issues of corruption and palace intrigue within the ruling family surrounding the kidnapping of Khalifa bin Fahed bin Mohammed Al Thani's brother, a popular royal and critic of the Emir. There is still suspicion, justified or not, that the Emir was complicit in the kidnapping from the onset. Coupled with the fact that 1b in random was paid to jihadist groups for their release adds exponentially to the climate of distrust harbored by not only parts of the Qatari royal family but Sunni Arabs in the GCC as well. If anything there will be increased aggression and isolation of Qatar within the GCC. If the land blockade ends it will sooner be due to a coup by Saudi Arabia and the UAE rather than any diplomatic resolution.
Most of the the Middle East events of this type have tended to take longer to resolve, instead of being fleeting.
Normalized relations with Qatar will happen prior to the IPO of Aramco.

Saudi has agreed to open its border temporarily for the Hajj this year, which begins August 19. While Riyadh may use this as a springboard for a permanent lifting of the blockade, I see no incentive for the Saudi government to announce a reopening of any kind ahead of that symbolic, goodwill date.
I think that this will not happen soon. Think it will happen more likely in 2019 than in the first months of 2018.
I think they have little incentive to move quickly

This disagreement is between two countries (more than two if you include other Gulf States) that have no voters to please, have absolute rulers with resources (oil, gas, money) and so are not under existential pressure to blink first. Both feel that powerful outside countries need them too much to force them to back down. So any reopening of the border would need to be preceded by some face saving resolutions to the dispute that does not look like capitulation, I don't see what that resolution could look like.

Thanks to @cdob63 for the article. Enforces my prediction that KSA is not currently looking to resolve the crisis and thus open the border with Qatar. Hence I have increased the likelihood that the border will not be opened before 1st of August 2018. http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/12/saudi-permanently-closes-land-border-qatar-171220062311052.html

http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/12/saudi-permanently-closes-land-border-qatar-171220062311052.html "Permanent"  sounds so....permanent.  Life being what it is, "permanent" may expire eventually.  Don't see it before next Fall, however.

I think it's hard to see a MBS-led Saudi Arabia backing down easily. The Saudis are on edge because of Iran's strategic wins of late in Iraq, Syria, Lebanon, and Yemen. While it's just about imaginable that the Saudis come to some sort of new understanding with the Muslim Brotherhood, and that this could lead to Saudi-Qatari reconciliation, I think it's likelier that the status quo continues indefinitely, especially given that US diplomacy is on the fritz.

Qatar's FX reserves are depleting rapidly, and seems unlikely that it will be able to deal with the embargo for a long time (my estimate: not beyond 1Q2018) - so some compromise is likely before too long.

As a resident in the UAE, I receive a lot of on the ground data on the situation and seems quite intractable. I haven't seen any meaningful progress, and Qatar isn't experiencing any material financial adverse effects with the Economist noting they are still strong with gas exports and trading with Turkey and Iran. I think it will be quite drawn out

Recent GCC annual summit has proven to be a bust with no resolution to the crisis. Only Kuwaiti and Qatari heads of states attended the summit. KSA & Co just sent its higher officials to attend the summit. 
http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/latest-uae-saudis-form-group-separate-gcc-51581182 To me this clearly shows that KSA & Co are currently not interested in changing their attitude towards Qatar and solving the current crisis. As my central assumption is that the border crossing will be opened as part more comprehensive solution to the crisis I see it happening being very unlikely.

Scenarios/Explanations: Before 1 February 2018 					12%
o	GCC annual meeting will likely focus on ending the conflict. Could bring the end to the conflict in the first half of the 2018. More likely in the second quarter due to limited time to the first way point (1st February 2018).
Between 1 February and 30 April 2018, inclusive		16%
o	See above.
Between 1 May and 31 July 2018, inclusive		7%
o	If the annual meeting will not produce positive end to the blockade I see it less likely to happen in the second half of the 2018. This might change in a new powerful intermediator would be introduced (US, Russia, China, EU).
Not before 1 August 2018				65%
o	There core rifts/differences between Qatar and KSA & Co – politics and economy infused with personal relationships and animosities. No side likely wants to give in and make concessions. Thus the end of the blockade and hence opening of the border crossing unlikely. Listing below certain facts and assumptions that have driven my prediction. Facts:
1. Qatari leaders have excluded the possibility that the country will comply with the 13 demands. Have stated that accepting these demands will result the effective end of Qatari foreign policy.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jun/23/close-al-jazeera-saudi-arabia-issues-qatar-with-13-demands-to-end-blockade 2. While the blockade first negatively affected Qatar, the country has weathered the blockade better than expected by deepening its diplomatic, trade and military ties to regional powers outside the GCC, especially Iran and Turkey.
https://www.thecipherbrief.com/no-end-sight-gulf-blockade-nudges-qatar-closer-iran 3. KSA FM has stated the political and economic boycott will continue until Qatar changes its policies for the better. Could last for another two years.
https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2017/9/6/saudis-threaten-qatar-with-two-more-years-of-blockade
The political and economic boycott will continue until Qatar changes its policies for the better, the Saudi foreign minister, Adel al-Jubeir, said at a news conference. 4. KSA has played a key role in at least two sovereign changes in QAT history
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jul/21/qatar-crisis-may-be-rooted-in-old-family-rivalries Assumptions:
1. Opening of the border will bound to Qatar and KSA making at least some progress in negotiating over the 13 demands that have been laid down by KSA & Co to end the blockade. This has today not happened as both sides ask for a zero-sum solution on their side. 2.Both sides are unlikely to make concessions that would satisfy the other side
a) KSA would certainly lose face if it was to back down from its 13 demands to Qatar
b) Qatar would as mentioned give up much of its foreign policy sovereignty. Also there is increased patriotic feelings in Qatar - people showing defiance against KSA and Co. who they see as "bullies". Qatar's own leadership likely has to take into account these feelings of the local populace.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/25/us-may-intervene-in-qatar-crisis-as-fears-grow-over-long-term-rupture 3. More to the crisis than at first meets the eye - core differences between the opposing sides in numerous issues (political, ideological, economical)
a)Likelihood that the issues not only political but also personal – KSA and UAE leaders want regime change? KSA as mentioned has before intervened in Qatar's internal affairs.
b) Battle of Wahhabi trends - Qatars more moderate, flexible vs KSA's more traditional conservative.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jul/21/qatar-crisis-may-be-rooted-in-old-family-rivalries
c) Regional competition lies at its root is a  between Qatar and the UAE and, increasingly, Saudi.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/25/us-may-intervene-in-qatar-crisis-as-fears-grow-over-long-term-rupture. 4. On the other hand blockade hurts both sides:
a) KSA and Co - Qatar is moving closer to the regional rivals of KSA. Cannot be excluded that KSA will want to cut its losses and look to bring QAT back to the fold turning back the positive effects the crisis has on IRN and TUR.
https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21730426-if-saudis-and-emiratis-will-not-trade-doha-iranians-will-boycott
b) Qatar has had to liquify some of its sovereign wealth fund (SWF) assets (approx. 13%) to pay for restructuring and redirecting many of its economic sectors that were effected by the blockade. While its SWF still stands at $300BN continued blockade could have a continued negative effect on it (especially if new sanctions could be imposed) which Qatar would want to contain.
http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/06/qatar-diplomatic-crisis-latest-updates-170605105550769.html
c) IMF has proposed that continue medium term rift could hurt GCC growth prospects
http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/06/qatar-diplomatic-crisis-latest-updates-170605105550769.html 5. Certain experts have suggested that  GCC annual meeting will be the first step to resolve the crisis
http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/kuwait/gcc-summit-could-be-beginning-of-end-of-qatar-crisis-1.2133813

Earlier this year, Saudi Arabia severed ties with Qatar in hopes of forcing a behavioral change, but it succeeded only in driving Doha away.  He claimed a list of 13 demands issued by Saudi Arabia and its allies in exchange for lifting the restrictions were impossible to meet, and a “clear indication that they don’t want [the agreement] to be accepted. “They don’t want to resolve this - they want our country in submission, which is the main reason they started the entire thing,” he added. “This is just part of a pattern of impulsive leadership … They entered this conflict with no exit strategy. “No one has identified a strategy; no one has any idea on the way forward with them.”
http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/saudi-arabia-lebanon-intimidation-campaign-middle-east-qatar-deputy-pm-hariri-blockade-destabilise-a8077606.html
Bilateral conflict will be extended, if there are no relevant developments and Saudi Arabia  wants to show firmness.
Qatar does not seem to change its policies, and Saudi Arabia want to display an iron fist in this matter, we shouldn't expect most change in the current status quo.
Governments that crack down take more than 8 months to say that foreigners are a good thing to allow into the country.
Rifts among Middle East nations are slow to heal, hence favouring a "later rather than sooner" approach to this question.
Qatar unrest will be continuing and Saudi long range goals vis a vis Iran will want to look hardline

It is never easy to predict what is going to happen in this region but this is probably going to go on for a while unless there is some form of compromise from  other sides which I don't really see coming.
Saudi and company have not found a way out of this one. Too much on their plate.
I don't think this crisis gets resolved anytime soon as none of the countries involved has any strong pressure to compromise.
